title: 105_hr331
content: The Act is titled the "Freedom and Self-Determination for the Former Soviet Union Act" and prohibits foreign assistance to Russia. Foreign assistance to Russia is restricted unless the President certifies to Congress that Russia's intelligence activities in the US are routine, they are progressing towards implementing a troop withdrawal agreement with Moldova, and they are not providing military assistance in Moldova's Transdniestra region. Russia is not providing military assistance in Moldova's Transdniestra region or to Bosnian Serb military units. They are also not providing intelligence information to Cuba or assistance with the signal intelligence facility at Lourdes. Russia is not providing goods or technology to countries like Iran, Iraq, Syria, China, or any country supporting terrorism. They are also in strict compliance with arms control agreements with the United States. Russia is in compliance with arms control agreements with the United States and has ceased strategic nuclear weapons modernization. The President must submit an annual report to Congress with certifications on Russia's adherence to trade and financial agreements. The President and Comptroller General must submit an annual report to Congress at the beginning of each fiscal year. The report should include the amount and effectiveness of foreign assistance provided to Russia, details on unexpended assistance, and an analysis of capital exported from Russia. SEC. 4. REQUIREMENT TO OPPOSE ASSISTANCE TO RUSSIA FROM INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS. The President should instruct the United States executive director of each international financial institution to oppose any assistance to Russia unless in compliance with section 2. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "foreign assistance" under this Act excludes humanitarian aid, educational and cultural exchanges, assistance for democratic reform, and safety upgrades for civilian nuclear power plants. The term "goods or technology" is also defined. The term "goods or technology" is defined as per the Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992. The term "international financial institution" includes various organizations such as the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund. The term "other independent states of the former Soviet Union" refers to countries like Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Kazakhstan. Countries in the former Soviet Union include Estonia, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, and Uzbekistan. The Act will be effective for fiscal years starting after its enactment, with exceptions for the fiscal year it is enacted, where certain provisions will apply immediately.
